qas.question: In what early technology was bitumen used?
What photographer used bitumen to make the earliest extant nature picture?
What feature of bitumen use in photography made it impractical?
During what period was bitumen used in printing processes?
Exposure to what natural element was necessary for early photographic plates?
What was used in early photomechanical technology?
What did spanish scientist Joseph Nicéphore Niépce use to make the oldest surviving photograph?
Exposure to darkness did what to the bitumen and also made it insoluble?
What did exposure to light harden and make soluble?
When did the Spanish scientist use bitumen to make a photograph from nature?

context: <b5_0><b6_0>Bitumen<b6_0/><b5_0/> was used in early <a0_0>photographic<a0_0/> technology. In <b9_0>1826 or 1827<b9_0/>, it was used by French scientist <a1_0>Joseph Nicéphore Niépce<a1_0/> to make the oldest surviving photograph from nature. The bitumen was thinly coated onto a pewter plate which was then exposed in a camera. Exposure to <a4_0>light<a4_0/> <b7_0>hardened<b7_0/> the <b8_0>bitumen<b8_0/> and made it insoluble, so that when it was subsequently rinsed with a solvent only the sufficiently light-struck areas remained. Many <a2_0>hours of exposure<a2_0/> in the camera were required, making bitumen impractical for ordinary photography, but from the <a3_0>1850s to the 1920s<a3_0/> it was in common use as a photoresist in the production of printing plates for various photomechanical printing processes.[not in citation given]
